Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of engraved rock art on a small piece of loose sandstone, showing landscape. The engraving shows the pecked figures of a cow, an unidentified quadruped animal (mythical?), and an unidentified shape, made clearer by the pecking removing grey patina to reveal an orange hue below. The cow figure is to the right, facing left with long upcurved horns that meet in the middle and is not infilled but for a chevron of pecked coat pattern marking on the rump. To the lower left of the cow is the infilled figure of an animal with four legs and a long tail, but no apparent head and neck and a pecked thin protuberance from the shoulder (mythical?). Above this is an unidentified pecked swirl shape. Wadi Hamra, Egypt. Scanned
Curator's comments: Wadi Hamra is a canyon-like valley with a relatively flat floor between one and 200m wide, curling more or less south into the Gilf Kebir plateau in Egypt’s Western Desert. There are three known rock art sites, all for engravings and first reported by Has Rhotert in 1952: The first is an old river terrace with numerous engravings of giraffe and a few of ostrich, cattle and abstract fan-shaped grooves, with stone circles and shallow depressions on the top. The second is several engravings further southwest. The third stands opposite the branch containing the first site: a rocky outcrop about 15 m high with a number of engravings along the base.
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
